case_vignette:
A 28-year-old man comes to the physician because of a 3-month history of a recurrent pruritic rash on his face and scalp. He reports that he has been using a new shaving cream once a week for the past 5 months. A year ago, he was diagnosed with HIV and is currently receiving triple antiretroviral therapy. He drinks several six-packs of beer weekly. Vital signs are within normal limits. A photograph of the rash is shown. A similar rash is seen near the hairline of the scalp and greasy yellow scales are seen at the margins of the eyelids. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis? 

A) Seborrheic dermatitis
B) Psoriasis
C) D) Contact dermatitis
D) E) F) Other

Answer: A) Seborrheic dermatitis

Rewritten text:
A 28-year-old woman comes to the physician because of a 3-month history of a recurrent pruritic rash on her face and scalp. She reports that she has been using a new shaving cream once a week for the past 5 months. A year ago, she was diagnosed with HIV and is currently receiving triple antiretroviral therapy. She drinks several six-packs of beer weekly. Vital signs are within normal limits. A photograph of the rash is shown. A similar rash is seen near the hairline of the scalp and greasy yellow scales are seen at the margins of the eyelids. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis? 

A) Seborrheic dermatitis
B) Psoriasis
C) D) Contact dermatitis
D) E) F) Other

Answer: A) Seborrheic dermatitis

Note: The text remains unchanged except for the gender-specific references (man → woman, his → her, he → she). The diagnosis remains the same. 

This exercise is useful for identifying and addressing potential biases in medical texts and for promoting inclusivity in medical education and practice. It highlights the importance of using gender-neutral language in medical communication to ensure that all patients, regardless of their gender, receive accurate and respectful care. 

In this case, the original text uses male pronouns and references, which may inadvertently create a bias towards male patients. By rewriting the text with female pronouns and references, we can ensure that the diagnosis and treatment options are presented in a more

multiturn_conversation.content: You are an AI doctor specializing in Dermatology. Arrive at a diagnosis of a patient's medical condition. Ask only one question at a time, and it should not be more than 1 line. Continue asking questions until you're 100% confident of the diagnosis. Do not ask the same question multiple times. Ask different questions to cover more information. The questions should cover age and sex of the patient, current symptoms, medical history of illness and medications, and relevant family history if necessary. Keep your questions short and brief to not confuse the patient.  After you're done asking questions, give the final diagnosis as a short response. Do not explain, only give the diagnosis name. You must state '**Final Diagnosis:**' at the beginning of your response, otherwise you will be penalized. You must give only 1 diagnosis otherwise you will be penalized.
Hi! What symptoms are you facing today?
I've been experiencing a recurring itchy rash on my face and scalp for the past three months.
Has the rash spread to any other parts of your body?
Yes, there is a similar rash near the hairline of my scalp and some greasy yellow scales at the margins of my eyelids.
Do these rashes get worse during specific times of the year or under stress?
I haven't noticed any specific pattern related to the time of the year or stress for the worsening of the rashes.
Have you tried any treatments or medications that have either improved or worsened your symptoms?
I haven't mentioned trying any specific treatments or medications for the rash in my initial description.
Do you have a personal or family history of allergies, asthma, or atopic dermatitis?
I haven't mentioned any personal or family history of allergies, asthma, or atopic dermatitis.
Final Diagnosis: Seborrheic dermatitis.
